awd_titl_txt: Development of the Electronic Test of Early Numeracy
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop and refine an electronic Test of Early Numeracy (e-TEN) in English and Spanish, focused on number and operations. The assessment will incorporate a learning trajectory that describes students' development of the understanding of number. The electronic assessment will allow for the test to adapt to students' responses and incorporate games to increase children's engagement with the tasks. These features take advantage of the electronic format. The achievement test will be designed to be efficient, user-friendly, affordable, and accessible for a variety of learning environments and a broad age range (3 to 8 years old).  The overarching goal of the assessment design is to create a measure that is more accurate, more accessible to a wider range of children, and easier to administer than existing measures. This project is funded by the Discovery Research Pre-K-12 Program, which funds research and development of STEM innovations and approaches in assessment, teaching and learning. 

The e-TEN will assess informal and formal knowledge of number and operations in domains including verbal counting, numbering, numerical relationships, and mental addition/subtraction. The items will be designed using domain-based learning trajectories that describe students' development of understanding of the topics. The test will be designed with some key characteristics. First, it will be semi-adaptive over six-month age spans. Second, it will have an electronic format that allows for uniform implementation and an efficient, user-friendly administration. The test will also be accessible to Spanish speakers using an inclusive assessment model. Finally, the game-based aspect should increase children's engagement and present more meaningful questions. The user-friendly aspect includes simplifying the assessment process compared to other tests of numeracy in early-childhood. The first phase of the development will test a preliminary version of the e-TEN to test its functionality and feasibility. The second phase will focus on norming of the items, reliability and validity. Reliability will be assessed using Item Response Theory methods and test-retest reliability measures. Validity will be examined using criterion-prediction validity and construct validity. The final phase of the work will include creating a Spanish version of the test including collecting data from bilingual children using both versions of the e-TEN.

por.por_cntn:
The electronic Test of Early Numeracy (eTEN) will be a highly useful assessment tool of early number and operations for educators and researchers. Educators need an easily operated, convenient, and powerful tool to quickly and accurately identify mathematically at-risk students who need additional support, screen young children for instructional readiness, and diagnosis specific conceptual and procedural strengths and weaknesses. Researchers need such a tool to evaluate early childhood programs such as Head Start, the efficacy of a curriculum such as Building Blocks, or the general impact of an experimental intervention such as the value of playing linear board games. This is particularly true of large-scale studies in which a concise measure of mathematical achievement is part of a larger battery of measures to examine the developmental relations between numeracy and other aspects of development or comparing early predictors of later achievement. Both educators and researchers need to be able to assess the numeracy of English- and Spanish-speaking children.

The eTEN will have numerous convenient features not all of which are available with current achievement or screening tests. 

  • The assessment will be appropriate for the entire period of early childhood mathematics education (pre-K to Grade 2) and be based on learning trajectories for seven key domains of early numeracy: verbal counting, numbering, numerical relations, numeral literacy, informal/mental arithmetic, place value, and formal/written multi-digit arithmetic.
  • The fully web-based app will give the assessment greater reach and support for multiple platforms commonly found in schools including Chromebooks, PCs, iPads, and Android tablets. The electronic format will permit semi-adaptive testing in a game-based (engaging) context in about 15 minutes and ensure easy, accurate, and standard item administration and scoring for better reliability and validity. A tester will control the test presentation and enter scoring data on one device (see e.g., Images 1 to 5). The game and test displays are presented on a second iPad (see, e.g., Images 1 and 3 to 5).
  • Semi-adaptive testing with unidimensional items will permit quick but powerful assessment. The first two items of the eTEN for each of twelve 6-month age is chosen to provide maximum discrimination of knowledge—to identify the child’s general location along a single dimension of knowledge levels expected for children ranging from 3- to 8-years of age. The next handful of items or so are chosen based on a child’s performance on previous items in such a way as to quickly and reliably zero in on a child’s “true” location along the single dimension of knowledge levels.
  • Embedding assessment in games is a relatively recent development but appears to make testing more engaging.
  • The item instructions, display(s), and examples are delivered by the avatars and the test displays (see, e.g., Images 3, 4, & 5) and manipulatives are presented virtually (see, e.g., Image 4). A tester, then, can focus on a child’s response and stimuli are presented in reliably standard manner better ensuring the test’s psychometric properties. A tester need only enter information about a child’s response, and item scores and the overall achievement score are automatically generated.
  • In the achievement mode, the printable report will provide feedback on a child’s performance for each item tested as well as comparative data to indicate a child’s relative developmental level as well as an overall normed (achievement) score. In diagnostic mode, the report will indicate provide feedback on a child’s performance and relative developmental level for each domain selected and tested. 
  • A Spanish version of the test will be available to accommodate the growing number of children whose primary language is Spanish.

Progress has been made on the first two of five goals of the long-range eTEN project.

Goal 1: Develop and refine the items for the eTEN including the game/activity context for administering the items and the program for delivering the tasks and collecting/reporting data. Using an iterative process of development and testing, the project created and refined 25 tasks or games/activities for administering 60 items, which—with partial credit—assess 144 developmental levels. Programming work continues with moving the eTEN to a Phaser.j platform to make it a fully web-based app; incorporating Spine2D to animate characters and objects in 2D video games; and automating reports.  

Goal 2: (a) Collect and (b) analyze calibration data and use it to create the branching program necessary for semi-adaptive testing. Analyses of the initial calibration data (n=794) and field testing of task indicated the need to add new tasks, add trials to existing tasks, and revise existing tasks. This necessitated re-calibrating the relative difficulty of items, which has been completed with at least 1,240 children. Analyzing the re-calibration is underway. Once done, work can begin on Goal 3 (collect/analyze data to determine national norms and psychometric properties); Goal 4 (create the Spanish translation and collect/analyze equivalence data for norming Spanish-speaking children); and Goal 5 (write tester's manual/guide).
